comment._content: The book cited by artolog indicates that she arrived in America in January 1915.

comment._content: NYT of April 22, 1917 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E04E7D8153AE433A... spells her last name Grouitch. Her husband was the Minister of Foreign Affairs in Serbia during WWI, but was a diplomat before and after, for Serbia and, later, Yugoslavia -- including a spell in Washington.

comment._content: hdl.loc.gov/loc.ndlpcoop/ichicdn.n064380 from the Chicago Daily News photo file, indicates that she visited Chicago in April 1915. The hat looks to be the same or very similar.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: She was also an American, born in West Virginia as Mabel Gordon-Dunlop (1881-1956). She was an alumna of the University of Chicago, went to Greece to study archaeology, and there met her future husband, Slavko Gruitch (spelled variously, I'm also seeing Gruji´c). She gets a mention in John B. Allcock and Antonia Young, Black Lambs and Grey Falcons: Women Travellers in the Balkans (Berghahn Books 2001): p. 73.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The Grouitch spelling finds more, including an October 28, 1912 NYT piece about a previous visit.  This reveals that she is American, the former Miss Mabel Gordon-Dunlop of Clarksburg, West Va.  She graduated from the University of Chicago, lectured on archaeology and art, and traveled to Greece to study art in 1901.  There she met the Serbian Charge d'Affaires in Athens and they were married in 1902.
